TearDown() is useful whenever I allocate external resources when running a
test. Files and sockets are two examples where I have used tearDown(). With
JUnit 3, tearDown() was also useful when allocating a lot of memory during a
test, where that memory was referenced by a field of the test. In JUnit 3,
test instances were not garbage collected at any guaranteed time, so it was
possible to use up the available memory with a large test suite. In such
cases, tearDown() would null out all the fields that referenced large
amounts of memory.

> Hi,
>
> I'm quite familiar with the purpose of tearDown(), I just fail to see
> the necessity of it. According to M. Feathers' "Working effectively
> with legacy code" unit tests don't access databases or communicate via
> a nreal network connection. I do know that his book's focus is not on
> JUnit, but I do think that he has a point there. So: without a
> database and a network connection, when it is really necessary to free
> up resources with tearDown()? Isn't garbage collecting enough?

In general, I find that just letting the garbage collector do it's job
is sufficient. I rarely use the tearDown() method for standard unit
tests.

That said, it is useful at times. At my previous employer, we also
used JUnit to drive some of our functional and load tests and at that
point, tearDown() started being useful.

So, don't feel that you have to use it, but remember that it's an
available option because when you do find that you need it, you'll be
glad it's there.
